elements.content: The neutral PCO derivative Ph3GePCO undergoes addition of borohydride to generate the anion [Ph3GePC­(H)­OBPh3]−. A subsequent deprotection strategy provides access to the monomethyl and dimethylformyl phosphines, Ph3GeP­(Me)­C­(H)O and Me2PC­(H)­O, respectively. The latter species which is the phosphorus analogue of DMF, was characterized and shown to complex via phosphorus to Ru. A computational study also highlights the similarities and differences between the P- and N-containing molecules.
elements.clean_text: The neutral PCO derivative Ph3GePCO undergoes addition of borohydride to generate the anion [Ph3GePC(H)OBPh3]-. A subsequent deprotection strategy provides access to the monomethyl and dimethylformyl phosphines, Ph3GeP(Me)C(H)O and Me2PC(H)O, respectively. The latter species which is the phosphorus analogue of DMF, was characterized and shown to complex via phosphorus to Ru. A computational study also highlights the similarities and differences between the P- and N-containing molecules.

elements.content: The recent resurgence of interest in the 2-phosphaethynolate anion and its reactivity has provided chemists with synthons to build inorganic variants of simple organic molecules in which phosphorus replaces nitrogen. For example, the Grützmacher group developed a synthetic route to the phosphorus-containing analogue of cyanuric acid, exploiting the reaction of Na­[PCO] with B-chlorodiisopinocampheylborane, followed by alcoholysis (). Goicoechea and co-workers employed a fatty acid to protonate Na­[PCO] to generate and isolate the phosphorus-containing analogue of isocyanic acid () whereas reaction with ammonium salts afforded the phosphorus-containing analogue of urea, H2PC­(O)­NH2 ().
elements.clean_text: The recent resurgence of interest in the 2-phosphaethynolate anion and its reactivity has provided chemists with synthons to build inorganic variants of simple organic molecules in which phosphorus replaces nitrogen. For example, the Grützmacher group developed a synthetic route to the phosphorus-containing analogue of cyanuric acid, exploiting the reaction of Na[PCO] with B-chlorodiisopinocampheylborane, followed by alcoholysis (). Goicoechea and co-workers employed a fatty acid to protonate Na[PCO] to generate and isolate the phosphorus-containing analogue of isocyanic acid () whereas reaction with ammonium salts afforded the phosphorus-containing analogue of urea, H2PC(O)NH2 ().

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" position="float">

<title>Phosphorus-Containing Analogue of Simple Molecules Derived From [PCO]<sup>−</sup>
</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr5" position="float" xlink:href="ja-2018-09266a_0005.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
elements.clean_text: 1  Phosphorus-Containing Analogue of Simple Molecules Derived From [PCO]-

elements.content: Among the simple phosphorus-containing small molecules that have not been prepared to date is the analogue of N,N-dimethylformamide, DMF, in which phosphorus replaces the nitrogen atom. While computational studies have examined the electronic structures of acyl and formylphosphines, and acylphosphines and formylphosphonates have been synthesized, only one example of an isolated formylphosphine exists in the literature. In 1999, Bertrand and co-workers isolated bis­(dialkylamido)­formylphosphines. Subsequent computational data suggested that the electron-donating properties of the −NR2 amide groups (R = cyclohexyl, isopropyl) on the P center were responsible for the observed stability of such species. Bertrand also showed a decrease in stability of formylphosphine oxides compared to the P­(III) counterpart with regard to decarbonylation, a feature previously observed in the chemistry of formylphosphonates. In a very recent communication, the simplest formylphosphine H2PC­(H)O was generated from PH3/CO ice mixtures under interstellar medium-like conditions and observed by mass spectrometric techniques.
elements.clean_text: Among the simple phosphorus-containing small molecules that have not been prepared to date is the analogue of N,N-dimethylformamide, DMF, in which phosphorus replaces the nitrogen atom. While computational studies have examined the electronic structures of acyl and formylphosphines, and acylphosphines and formylphosphonates have been synthesized, only one example of an isolated formylphosphine exists in the literature. In 1999, Bertrand and co-workers isolated bis(dialkylamido)formylphosphines. Subsequent computational data suggested that the electron-donating properties of the -NR2 amide groups (R = cyclohexyl, isopropyl) on the P center were responsible for the observed stability of such species. Bertrand also showed a decrease in stability of formylphosphine oxides compared to the P(III) counterpart with regard to decarbonylation, a feature previously observed in the chemistry of formylphosphonates. In a very recent communication, the simplest formylphosphine H2PC(H)O was generated from PH3/CO ice mixtures under interstellar medium-like conditions and observed by mass spectrometric techniques.

elements.content: Current synthetic strategies to access acylphosphines require lengthy syntheses involving the use of pyrophoric and toxic reagents such as PH3, P­(SiMe3)3 and volatile acyl chlorides. Noting that the previously described phosphorus-containing analogues of small molecules were prepared from salts of [PCO]−, we envisioned a strategy in which a protecting group would allow addition of a nucleophile to the PCO fragment while subsequent deprotection would allow for facile installation of a range of alkyl groups. To this end, we report a synthetic protocol exploiting the species Ph3GePCO to effect the synthesis of P,P-dimethylformylphosphine, Me2PC­(H)­O, the phosphorus analogue of DMF, while a computational study explores the structural and electronic differences between the nitrogen and phosphorus congeners.
elements.clean_text: Current synthetic strategies to access acylphosphines require lengthy syntheses involving the use of pyrophoric and toxic reagents such as PH3, P(SiMe3)3 and volatile acyl chlorides. Noting that the previously described phosphorus-containing analogues of small molecules were prepared from salts of [PCO]-, we envisioned a strategy in which a protecting group would allow addition of a nucleophile to the PCO fragment while subsequent deprotection would allow for facile installation of a range of alkyl groups. To this end, we report a synthetic protocol exploiting the species Ph3GePCO to effect the synthesis of P,P-dimethylformylphosphine, Me2PC(H)O, the phosphorus analogue of DMF, while a computational study explores the structural and electronic differences between the nitrogen and phosphorus congeners.

elements.content: The reactions of K­[HBPh3] with Ph3GePCO at ambient temperature in THF generated [K]­[Ph3GePC­(H)­OBPh3] ([K]­[1]), involving nucleophilic hydride addition to the carbon and B–O bond formation (). While this species gives rise to one broad resonance in the 11B­{1H} NMR spectrum at 6.4 ppm, the 31P­{1H} NMR spectrum displays resonances at δ 23.9 and 0.6 ppm in an intensity ratio of 1:0.8, attributable to (E) and (Z) isomers, respectively. These spectroscopic features are similar to those seen for (E/Z)-[Na­(HP = CHO)­(DME) x ]. 1H–1H exchange spectroscopy (EXSY) experiments confirmed that these species are in equilibrium and interconvert on the NMR time scale with a rate constant of 0.6 s–1 (see ). Addition of 18-crown-6 to the above reaction gave [K­(18-crown-6)]­[Ph3GePC­(H)­OBPh3] ([K­(18-crown-6)]­[1]) (). X-ray diffraction studies of single crystals of the (E)-([K­(18-crown-6)]­[1] obtained from a saturated benzene/pentane solution () confirmed the formulation of anion [1]. The structural data revealed Ge–P, P–C, C–O and O–B distances of 2.274(4), 1.711(9), 1.32(1) and 1.71(1) Å, respectively, as well as the (E)-orientation about the CP double bond.
elements.clean_text: The reactions of K[HBPh3] with Ph3GePCO at ambient temperature in THF generated [K][Ph3GePC(H)OBPh3] ([K][1]), involving nucleophilic hydride addition to the carbon and B-O bond formation (). While this species gives rise to one broad resonance in the 11B{1H} NMR spectrum at 6.4 ppm, the 31P{1H} NMR spectrum displays resonances at δ 23.9 and 0.6 ppm in an intensity ratio of 1:0.8, attributable to (E) and (Z) isomers, respectively. These spectroscopic features are similar to those seen for (E/Z)-[Na(HP = CHO)(DME) x ]. 1H-1H exchange spectroscopy (EXSY) experiments confirmed that these species are in equilibrium and interconvert on the NMR time scale with a rate constant of 0.6 s-1 (see ). Addition of 18-crown-6 to the above reaction gave [K(18-crown-6)][Ph3GePC(H)OBPh3] ([K(18-crown-6)][1]) (). X-ray diffraction studies of single crystals of the (E)-([K(18-crown-6)][1] obtained from a saturated benzene/pentane solution () confirmed the formulation of anion [1]. The structural data revealed Ge-P, P-C, C-O and O-B distances of 2.274(4), 1.711(9), 1.32(1) and 1.71(1) Å, respectively, as well as the (E)-orientation about the CP double bond.

elements.content: POV-ray depiction of the anion of (E)-([K­(18-crown-6)]­[1]. Hydrogen atoms except the formyl CH and the cation are omitted for clarity. H, white; C, black; P, orange; O, red; B, light green; Ge, dark green.
elements.clean_text: 1  POV-ray depiction of the anion of (E)-([K(18-crown-6)][1]. Hydrogen atoms except the formyl CH and the cation are omitted for clarity. H, white; C, black; P, orange; O, red; B, light green; Ge, dark green.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch2" position="float">
<label>2</label>
<caption>
<title>Synthesis of [K]­[<bold>1</bold>]–<bold>4</bold>
</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr6" position="float" xlink:href="ja-2018-09266a_0006.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
elements.clean_text: 2  Synthesis of [K][1]-4

elements.content: Treatment of [K]­[1] with one equivalent of CH3I yielded multiple products as evidenced by 31P­{1H} NMR spectroscopy; however, treatment of [K]­[1] with CH3I in the presence of the fluoride source, [NBu4]­[Ph3SiF2], afforded a single major product, as evidenced by the 31P­{1H} NMR doublet resonance at −46.3 ppm (2 J PH = 83 Hz). The corresponding 1H NMR spectrum showed a doublet resonance at 11.0 ppm (2 J PH = 83 Hz), which collapsed into a singlet upon 31P decoupling. The 19F­{1H} and 11B­{1H} NMR spectra showed the formation of the anion [Ph3BF]− and Ph3SiF. These data were consistent with quantitative borane abstraction, and methylation at P generating Ph3GeP­(Me)­C­(H)O 2 (). All efforts to isolate 2 from the complex product mixture were unsuccessful. Nonetheless, the generation of 2 reveals that the presence of the oxophilic BPh3 fragment in [K]­[1] allows for methylation at phosphorus, with subsequent borane capture by fluoride.
elements.clean_text: Treatment of [K][1] with one equivalent of CH3I yielded multiple products as evidenced by 31P{1H} NMR spectroscopy; however, treatment of [K][1] with CH3I in the presence of the fluoride source, [NBu4][Ph3SiF2], afforded a single major product, as evidenced by the 31P{1H} NMR doublet resonance at -46.3 ppm (2 J PH = 83 Hz). The corresponding 1H NMR spectrum showed a doublet resonance at 11.0 ppm (2 J PH = 83 Hz), which collapsed into a singlet upon 31P decoupling. The 19F{1H} and 11B{1H} NMR spectra showed the formation of the anion [Ph3BF]- and Ph3SiF. These data were consistent with quantitative borane abstraction, and methylation at P generating Ph3GeP(Me)C(H)O 2 (). All efforts to isolate 2 from the complex product mixture were unsuccessful. Nonetheless, the generation of 2 reveals that the presence of the oxophilic BPh3 fragment in [K][1] allows for methylation at phosphorus, with subsequent borane capture by fluoride.

elements.content: The sequestration of BPh3 by fluoride prompted us to probe the possibility of sequestering [GePh3]+ via P–Ge bond cleavage using two equivalents of CH3I and [NBu4]­[Ph3SiF2]. Indeed, to that end, reaction of [K]­[1] with two equivalents of [NBu4]­[Ph3SiF2] and CH3I in THF-d 8 yielded a single phosphorus-containing product, 3 (). The 31P­{1H} NMR spectrum showed a singlet resonance at δ −22.4 ppm which expanded to a doublet upon proton coupling (2 J PH = 68 Hz). Further multinuclear NMR experiments (1H, 11B­{1H}, 19F­{1H}) confirmed the formation of Ph3GeF, Ph3SiF, [NBu4]­[Ph3BF] and [NBu4]­[I], while precipitation of KI was also evident. In the 1H NMR spectrum, two doublet resonances were observed at δ 11.50 ppm (2 J PH = 68 Hz) and 1.23 ppm (2 J PH = 2 Hz). Both collapsed to singlets in the 1H­{31P} NMR spectrum. In the 13C­{1H} NMR spectrum, the diagnostic resonance corresponding to the formyl carbon can be observed at 225.1 ppm (1 J PC = 49 Hz) and the methyl resonance at 6.1 ppm (1 J PC = 2 Hz). These observations are consistent with the double methylation at phosphorus and the formulation of the phosphorus-containing product 3 as Me2PC­(H)­O, the phosphorus analogue of N,N-dimethylformamide.
elements.clean_text: The sequestration of BPh3 by fluoride prompted us to probe the possibility of sequestering [GePh3]+ via P-Ge bond cleavage using two equivalents of CH3I and [NBu4][Ph3SiF2]. Indeed, to that end, reaction of [K][1] with two equivalents of [NBu4][Ph3SiF2] and CH3I in THF-d 8 yielded a single phosphorus-containing product, 3 (). The 31P{1H} NMR spectrum showed a singlet resonance at δ -22.4 ppm which expanded to a doublet upon proton coupling (2 J PH = 68 Hz). Further multinuclear NMR experiments (1H, 11B{1H}, 19F{1H}) confirmed the formation of Ph3GeF, Ph3SiF, [NBu4][Ph3BF] and [NBu4][I], while precipitation of KI was also evident. In the 1H NMR spectrum, two doublet resonances were observed at δ 11.50 ppm (2 J PH = 68 Hz) and 1.23 ppm (2 J PH = 2 Hz). Both collapsed to singlets in the 1H{31P} NMR spectrum. In the 13C{1H} NMR spectrum, the diagnostic resonance corresponding to the formyl carbon can be observed at 225.1 ppm (1 J PC = 49 Hz) and the methyl resonance at 6.1 ppm (1 J PC = 2 Hz). These observations are consistent with the double methylation at phosphorus and the formulation of the phosphorus-containing product 3 as Me2PC(H)O, the phosphorus analogue of N,N-dimethylformamide.

elements.content: Separation of compound 3 from the byproducts was accomplished by a trap-to-trap distillation at ambient temperature and ca. 10–3 Torr. NMR spectroscopic analysis confirmed the colorless liquid obtaining from distillation contained a clean THF solution of compound 3. The T1 relaxation time of compound 3 was determined to be 5.77(2) seconds via inverse-gated recovery 31P NMR experiments. This allowed the determination of the isolated yield of 3 via integration of 31P NMR spectra where a known amount of PPh3 was added as an internal standard. In this fashion, the yield of 3 following distillation was calculated to be 50%. The synthesis of 3 is amenable to scale up and can be repeated starting with several hundred milligrams of [K]­[1].
elements.clean_text: Separation of compound 3 from the byproducts was accomplished by a trap-to-trap distillation at ambient temperature and ca. 10-3 Torr. NMR spectroscopic analysis confirmed the colorless liquid obtaining from distillation contained a clean THF solution of compound 3. The T1 relaxation time of compound 3 was determined to be 5.77(2) seconds via inverse-gated recovery 31P NMR experiments. This allowed the determination of the isolated yield of 3 via integration of 31P NMR spectra where a known amount of PPh3 was added as an internal standard. In this fashion, the yield of 3 following distillation was calculated to be 50%. The synthesis of 3 is amenable to scale up and can be repeated starting with several hundred milligrams of [K][1].

elements.content: Solutions of 3 in THF show no signs of decomposition after weeks in the freezer or after refluxing for 8 h. In contrast to the observation of Bertrand for (R2N)2PC­(H)­O, photolysis of 3 does not lead to clean decarbonylation. Instead, multiple unidentified products are formed after <1 h of irradiation. Interestingly, 3 proved to be stable to the presence of water in solution, and THF solutions of 3 are stable many hours upon exposure to ambient air.
elements.clean_text: Solutions of 3 in THF show no signs of decomposition after weeks in the freezer or after refluxing for 8 h. In contrast to the observation of Bertrand for (R2N)2PC(H)O, photolysis of 3 does not lead to clean decarbonylation. Instead, multiple unidentified products are formed after <1 h of irradiation. Interestingly, 3 proved to be stable to the presence of water in solution, and THF solutions of 3 are stable many hours upon exposure to ambient air.

elements.content: A solution of compound 3 in THF was added to solid [Ru­(p-cymene)­Cl2]2, which led to the formation of a clear orange solution. Analysis by NMR spectroscopy was consistent with the formation of a metal-complex 4 as evidenced by the doublet resonance at δ 17.6 ppm (2 J PH = 100 Hz) in the 31P NMR spectrum and a doublet resonance in the diagnostic downfield region at δ 11.1 ppm (2 J PH = 100 Hz) in the 1H NMR spectrum (). The significant downfield shift of the phosphorus resonance and the increased 2 J PH coupling constant value are consistent with the expected formation of a phosphorus–ruthenium bond and the formulation of the product as Ru­(p-cymene)­Cl2(PMe2C­(H)­O). The connectivity of 4 was confirmed by X-ray diffraction experiments of dark red crystals grown from a THF/hexane mixture at room temperature (). The geometry of 4 is typically distorted tetrahedral at both Ru and P. The Ru–P distance was found to be 2.3087(9) Å, while the PCMe, PC­(O) and CO distances are 1.813(4), 1.874(4) and 1.206(5) Å, respectively. Previous computational studies by Tsipis suggested that coordination of acyl and formylphosphines to metal centers via P (κ1-P), O (κ1-O), or both (κ2-P,O). The isolation of 4 demonstrates that, at least for 3, the κ1-P binding is preferred.
elements.clean_text: A solution of compound 3 in THF was added to solid [Ru(p-cymene)Cl2]2, which led to the formation of a clear orange solution. Analysis by NMR spectroscopy was consistent with the formation of a metal-complex 4 as evidenced by the doublet resonance at δ 17.6 ppm (2 J PH = 100 Hz) in the 31P NMR spectrum and a doublet resonance in the diagnostic downfield region at δ 11.1 ppm (2 J PH = 100 Hz) in the 1H NMR spectrum (). The significant downfield shift of the phosphorus resonance and the increased 2 J PH coupling constant value are consistent with the expected formation of a phosphorus-ruthenium bond and the formulation of the product as Ru(p-cymene)Cl2(PMe2C(H)O). The connectivity of 4 was confirmed by X-ray diffraction experiments of dark red crystals grown from a THF/hexane mixture at room temperature (). The geometry of 4 is typically distorted tetrahedral at both Ru and P. The Ru-P distance was found to be 2.3087(9) Å, while the PCMe, PC(O) and CO distances are 1.813(4), 1.874(4) and 1.206(5) Å, respectively. Previous computational studies by Tsipis suggested that coordination of acyl and formylphosphines to metal centers via P (κ1-P), O (κ1-O), or both (κ2-P,O). The isolation of 4 demonstrates that, at least for 3, the κ1-P binding is preferred.

elements.content: POV-ray depiction of 4. Selected hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity. H, white; C, black; P, orange; O, red; Ru, magenta. Cl, light blue.
elements.clean_text: 2  POV-ray depiction of 4. Selected hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity. H, white; C, black; P, orange; O, red; Ru, magenta. Cl, light blue.

elements.content: The nature of 3 in comparison to DMF was considered. In DMF, the N-bound methyl groups are inequivalent due to the π-conjugation of the N-lone pair and the carbonyl fragment. In contrast, the P-bound methyl groups in 3 exhibit a single 1H resonance, consistent with free rotation about the P-carbonyl bond at room temperature. To further probe this issue, computations were performed at the B3LYP/def2-QZVPP level of theory, including Grimme’s D3 dispersion correction with Becke-Johnson damping. These results were corroborated by calculations using the BP86 functional and using the post-Hartree–Fock MP2 method, and incorporating a polarizable continuum model to account for the effects of THF as solvent (see ). The ground state (GS) features a pyramidal phosphorus center with the lone pair orthogonal to the PC­(O)H plane. The three higher energy structures (TS anti , TS syn and TS planar ) are all first-order saddle points on the potential energy surface, with exactly one imaginary frequency. TS anti and TS syn both feature pyramidal phosphorus centers that differ by the orientation of the phosphorus lone pair (). The bond metric data () show that GS has a slightly shorter PC­(O) bond (1.846 Å) than the corresponding distance in TS anti and TS syn of 1.889 and 1.909 Å, respectively. In addition, the sum of angles around the phosphorus center in the GS of 301.5° is significantly higher than the angles of 288.6 and 292.1° computed for TS anti and TS syn , respectively. These observations are consistent with a small stabilizing interaction arising from the donation of electron density from the phosphorus lone pair into the CO π* orbital in GS. The transition state TS anti indicates a relatively small barrier to rotation around the PC­(O) of only 13.8 kJ/mol, consistent with the observation of equivalent methyl groups in the 1H NMR spectrum of 3 at room temperature. In contrast, the corresponding barrier for NC­(O) rotation in DMF was computed to be 86.2 kJ/mol at the same level of theory (see ), which is consistent with experimental evaluations of this barrier.
elements.clean_text: The nature of 3 in comparison to DMF was considered. In DMF, the N-bound methyl groups are inequivalent due to the π-conjugation of the N-lone pair and the carbonyl fragment. In contrast, the P-bound methyl groups in 3 exhibit a single 1H resonance, consistent with free rotation about the P-carbonyl bond at room temperature. To further probe this issue, computations were performed at the B3LYP/def2-QZVPP level of theory, including Grimme's D3 dispersion correction with Becke-Johnson damping. These results were corroborated by calculations using the BP86 functional and using the post-Hartree-Fock MP2 method, and incorporating a polarizable continuum model to account for the effects of THF as solvent (see ). The ground state (GS) features a pyramidal phosphorus center with the lone pair orthogonal to the PC(O)H plane. The three higher energy structures (TS  anti , TS  syn  and TS  planar ) are all first-order saddle points on the potential energy surface, with exactly one imaginary frequency. TS  anti  and TS  syn  both feature pyramidal phosphorus centers that differ by the orientation of the phosphorus lone pair (). The bond metric data () show that GS has a slightly shorter PC(O) bond (1.846 Å) than the corresponding distance in TS  anti  and TS  syn  of 1.889 and 1.909 Å, respectively. In addition, the sum of angles around the phosphorus center in the GS of 301.5° is significantly higher than the angles of 288.6 and 292.1° computed for TS  anti  and TS  syn , respectively. These observations are consistent with a small stabilizing interaction arising from the donation of electron density from the phosphorus lone pair into the CO π* orbital in GS. The transition state TS  anti  indicates a relatively small barrier to rotation around the PC(O) of only 13.8 kJ/mol, consistent with the observation of equivalent methyl groups in the 1H NMR spectrum of 3 at room temperature. In contrast, the corresponding barrier for NC(O) rotation in DMF was computed to be 86.2 kJ/mol at the same level of theory (see ), which is consistent with experimental evaluations of this barrier.

elements.content: Energy profile diagram showing the interconversion of the ground state of 3 via three different transition states.
elements.clean_text: 3  Energy profile diagram showing the interconversion of the ground state of 3 via three different transition states.

elements.content: The computed transition state TS planar , which features a planar phosphorus center, exhibits a significantly shorter PC­(O) bond length (1.754 Å). This geometry results from an appreciable overlap between the phosphorus lone pair and the CO π* orbital. While this planarization of the phosphorus center is high energy (82.4 kJ/mol) and corresponds to the barrier to pyramidal inversion at phosphorus, it is significantly lower in energy than that computed for trialkylphosphines (see , PMe3: 175.8 kJ/mol, similar to recently reported value of 180.7 kJ/mol). These results are consistent with previous computational studies on related acyl and formylphosphines.
elements.clean_text: The computed transition state TS  planar , which features a planar phosphorus center, exhibits a significantly shorter PC(O) bond length (1.754 Å). This geometry results from an appreciable overlap between the phosphorus lone pair and the CO π* orbital. While this planarization of the phosphorus center is high energy (82.4 kJ/mol) and corresponds to the barrier to pyramidal inversion at phosphorus, it is significantly lower in energy than that computed for trialkylphosphines (see , PMe3: 175.8 kJ/mol, similar to recently reported value of 180.7 kJ/mol). These results are consistent with previous computational studies on related acyl and formylphosphines.

elements.content: The ground state structures of 3 and DMF were further probed by natural bond orbital (NBO) analysis. The donor/acceptor interaction of the pnictogen lone pair into the CO π* is 21.5 kJ/mol in 3, which is significantly smaller than the corresponding value of 289.1 kJ/mol in DMF. Natural resonance theory (NRT) for 3, DMF and pivaldehyde show that the major resonance contribution in each case is from the structure with an EC single bond and a CO double bond, as expected (). The resonance structure arising from donation of the P lone pair into the CO π* in 3 (P2), is non-negligible, but contributes only 4.0% to the overall structure. The corresponding resonance form for DMF (N2), is a more significant contribution (31.8%). Smaller contributions corresponding to negative hyperconjugation from the lone pairs on oxygen into the EC­(O) and HC­(O) σ* orbitals are also significant for all three species (see ). These data suggest that 3 is similar in electronic structure to pivaldehyde, which is consistent with the notion that phosphorus is the “carbon copy”.
elements.clean_text: The ground state structures of 3 and DMF were further probed by natural bond orbital (NBO) analysis. The donor/acceptor interaction of the pnictogen lone pair into the CO π* is 21.5 kJ/mol in 3, which is significantly smaller than the corresponding value of 289.1 kJ/mol in DMF. Natural resonance theory (NRT) for 3, DMF and pivaldehyde show that the major resonance contribution in each case is from the structure with an EC single bond and a CO double bond, as expected (). The resonance structure arising from donation of the P lone pair into the CO π* in 3 (P2), is non-negligible, but contributes only 4.0% to the overall structure. The corresponding resonance form for DMF (N2), is a more significant contribution (31.8%). Smaller contributions corresponding to negative hyperconjugation from the lone pairs on oxygen into the EC(O) and HC(O) σ* orbitals are also significant for all three species (see ). These data suggest that 3 is similar in electronic structure to pivaldehyde, which is consistent with the notion that phosphorus is the "carbon copy".

elements.content: Natural resonance theory (NRT) analysis of 3, DMF and pivaldehyde.
elements.clean_text: 4  Natural resonance theory (NRT) analysis of 3, DMF and pivaldehyde.

elements.content: In summary, a neutral derivative of the PCO anion, Ph3GePCO, has been used to generate the anion 1 [Ph3GePC­(H)­OBPh3]− while subsequent treatment with CH3I and [NBu4]­[Ph3SiF2] effects removal of the protecting groups and selective methylation at phosphorus, ultimately generating P,P-dimethylformylphosphine, Me2PC­(H)­O. This isolable phosphorus-containing analogue of DMF is computed to have a low barrier to P–C­(O) bond rotation in contrast to the inhibited C–N bond rotation in DMF. We are continuing to examine the utility of Ph3GePCO in the synthesis of other simple phosphorus-containing molecules.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a neutral derivative of the PCO anion, Ph3GePCO, has been used to generate the anion 1 [Ph3GePC(H)OBPh3]- while subsequent treatment with CH3I and [NBu4][Ph3SiF2] effects removal of the protecting groups and selective methylation at phosphorus, ultimately generating P,P-dimethylformylphosphine, Me2PC(H)O. This isolable phosphorus-containing analogue of DMF is computed to have a low barrier to P-C(O) bond rotation in contrast to the inhibited C-N bond rotation in DMF. We are continuing to examine the utility of Ph3GePCO in the synthesis of other simple phosphorus-containing molecules.
